review name: Spending a little more money goes a long way
review text:
I went from a cheap mr coffee maker to this, the different is insane.
I have brewed about 5 cups now, 2 k cups and 3 ground coffee, and 1 bold brew. Everything works really well and honestly props to the design team on this one. There are very niche things that I thought would be a minor inconvenience that ended up being well designed instead. For example, the water can be taken out, which is normal, but it stands upright if you need to set it somewhere to fill it up. The funnel and front-opening design of the k cup slot or coffee slot is also super easy to access and stress free

Biggest complaint for people: It takes time to brew
Like I mentioned I went from a mr coffee to this, and the mr coffee made coffee a lot faster
But the taste was absolutely terrible and I used to think it was the ground coffee's fault
Come to find out, this maker makes way tastier coffee with less grounds used.
SO yeah, it takes longer to brew, but I would take that over a fast brew cup of terrible coffee any day. I dont see how people have been complaining about that

Also grounds leaking into your cup / spilling out of the machine
If you have a brain, this wont happen. People who have had spilling issues did not read the instructions about flushing out the system if you stop a brew mid way, and grounds getting into your cup usually means your coffee is finer than the filter (Use a coarser grind). To be honest though, even with fine coffee there was minimal leakage into the cup

I never imagined how much more you could get by shelling out 40-50 more bucks, Worth it all the way I'd buy it again any time.

review name: Cheap water reservoir and SO SLOW - But great for an RV.
review text:
UPDATE: We couldn't take it anymore. We replaced this device with another brand. HOWEVER, we did find the PERFECT use case for this device. It doesn't store water, and it doesn't keep the water preheated, so it's PERFECT in our RV. No water to go bad between trips, and no wasted electricity when we're running off of battery power.
This is a super simple to use little coffee maker and it brews a decent cup of coffee. That being said, the reservoir is made of super thin plastic and it cracked the second time that I pulled it off to fill it, so use a pitcher or something and fill it, don't remove it, it won't stand up to it. Also, this coffee maker is energy efficient, I guess, because it does not preheat any water. When you push the buttons to make a cup of coffee, that's when it fills the interior water tank and heats the water. As a result it takes FOREVER to brew a cup of coffee. Go read a book, take a nap, something, because you'll get bored waiting for your cup. (And subsequent cups don't go any faster, it doesn't like "warm up" and then go faster. It's cold water in... heat it... make coffee.... cold water in... heat it.... make coffee.)
I like it, it works, but don't try using it in an office environment or other high use area; you'll get a line out the door waiting.

review text:
I haven't had a single cup coffee machine for some years but decided to got one again because I would like to just make a single cup at a time instead of a whole or half pot and wind up reheating later cups because I don't drink them really fast on my weekends and my regular coffee pot turns off after an hour. Hamilton Beach is a brand I've purchased other products of and never had any issues too. When the product arrived the whole thing was in a plastic bag and it was all wet inside the bag not on the outside. I'm guessing they water test the unit and somehow it got wet and they just packed it up. I was alarmed, but luckily it didn't have any mildew odor or any other smell, but I thoroughly cleaned every piece of the unit with detergent and water and ran some vinegar through it and several water only runs to make sure it was safe.

I've used this unit for several weeks now and so far it doesn't take long for it to make a cup of coffee at all. I've used both k-cups and coffee grounds and the gadget performes well using either. I do wish the ground coffee basket was slightly larger because I like my coffee pretty strong, but it doesn't make this not worth checking out. I also have seen some different devices that have the water reservoir on the side which would probably be slightly more convenient because I have to pull it away from under my cupboards to refill and reach my head around to see the water level, but it's just a minor inconvenience, though it could have swayed my decision if I would have thought about it at the time.

The cup predetermined cup sizes seem to slightly vary every brew because using the same cup I'll notice the fill level will sometimes be slightly different, this only matters because I add creamer to my coffee and sometimes have to pour a little out to have enough room for my desired amount of creamer.

review name: An Average Single Serve Coffee Machine With Cup Options and Water Reservoir
review text:
Amazon features an array of single-serve countertop coffee makers in the $50 - $100 price range. This Hamilton Beach single-serve coffee maker has a price point of $80, or at the higher range of average. At this price, you would expect some nice technology and a machine featuring good finishes. Overall, this unit has some very good features, but some finish and cheap fabrication issues combine to make this an average machine...a daily work horse that has foregone any nice embellishments.

Of course, it has some very good features that make this worthy of a purchase consideration. As a single-brew machine, it does give you the option to use a K-cup pod and also includes an adapter for you to fill with your own coffee. That is a nice touch. Like many single-cup machines, you are given the option of how many ounces you want to brew for your cup...from 8 oz up to 14 oz. There is an iced coffee function that allows you to remove the coffee mug stand in order to fit a larger size glass to hold your ice and drip coffee. Looking at these features alone, this is a decent unit that should serve your household for a long period of time.

However, most coffee drinkers store their coffee makers out on their kitchen counter...always in plain view. Because of this, some competitor models will add a satin finish, use better plastics, add metal bands and face plates and more... in an effort to make their units more classy so they look nice in addition to working well. For this appliance, Hamilton Beach did not go all out. The plastic used has a cheap look to it and the finish of our unit had dull spots and uneven color areas. The plastic used for the cup rest is not the hard plastic used by some competitors. While these finish details don't impact the operation of the brewer or the taste of the coffee, they affect the aesthetics of what rests on top of the counter.

In this review, this brewer gets four stars because it is a decent coffee machine. We've taken away one star because of the inattention to finish.

review name: as good as "K" brand at lower price and smaller footprint, easier to clean
review text: At first it looks like this has a smaller tank than the "K" brand, but it is actually the same size. The shape and position (back of unit) makes it look smaller. The instructions say to have a minimum of 16 ounces in the tank which would make the useful reservoir only 34 oz, but it did not stop brewing when the tank was almost empty. Overall, the footprint is much smaller than the classic "K" model, though having the water tank in the back could be more cumbersome to fill. BUT, it is so much easier to get off since it just slides in place. With the "K" model, you have to kind of angle it in - often spilling the water on the counter. I use a container to fill my because it is such a pain. The "K" model also has a filter which this one does not - don't know if that is good or bad, but it makes the "K" model near impossible to clean. There is only the tiny valve at the bottom of this and the shape is much easier to work with. The temperature is not adjustable like the "K" classic, and comes out about the same at about 170 degrees when it fills a ceramic cup (the second time). The part that holds the coffee pod (or the included refillable pod) does not snap in place like on the "K" brand, making it easier to clean. It is a little noisier than the "K" model, but not so much that it is annoying. My unit actually had water in it when I opened the box - hopefully from testing but I would think they would want to make sure it was dry before packaging! The price is much less than a similar "K" model as well.

review name: Perfect for brewing directly into a 16 ounce tumbler
review text: In the later stages of my career I was assigned to a 3 year project which kept me away from home for extended periods, basically what we call "geo-batching" it. I had a fully furnished apartment and it came with one of these coffee makers. I came to love being able to brew coffee directly into my 16 ounce yeti tumbler on my way out the door, perfect for those dark starts to my work day. I first started using k-cups but found that the provided filter for ground coffee worked much better giving me a great cup of coffee and saving the expense of the K-cups as well. This unit is simple to operate, just place the k-cup into the hopper, close the lid and hit either the 12 or 14 ounce button, about a minute and a half later you'll have a nice cup of coffee. The same applies if your using the provided filter to brew ground coffee. If your grinding your own coffee, make sure that you grind for drip coffee, any thing finer will result in a mess. This unit is nice and compact as well, so it will take less counter top space than other K-cup capable models out there. I typically do not drink iced coffee, so can't speak for that functionality. Overall like this coffee maker and would recommend.

review name: Nice single brew, can use K cups or your own coffee grounds, 3 sizes of brew
review text:
I currently own the Hamilton Beach FlexBrew 2-way coffee maker that I purchased locally so I am already familiar with the single brew.

As I don't particularly care for the coffee offered at work and would rather not drown my coffee in creamer, I decided to get this to use at my desk so I can make coffee of my choosing. There is a kitchen area so filling the reservoir with water & rinsing the coffee grounds filter is not a problem.

This machine has a 40 oz water reservoir so you don't need to refill after every cup as my current home machine does.
So that is 5 8oz or 4 10oz or 2 14 oz servings before you need to refill. You can fill a bit above the max line. The bottom removable tray is also storage for the K-cup adapter or coffee ground adapter.

There is the option for regular brew or bold. I believe the bold setting makes the water a little hotter. Either way you get a hot cup of coffee every time.

This takes about 3 minutes to make a 8oz, 3 1/2 to make a 10 and about 5 to make a 14. This is measured from when you hit the brew button until this stops making noise and the brew light goes out. You can take about 15 seconds off this to when you can remove your cup. I was hoping this would be quicker then my FlexBrew 2-way when using the single side, but when running both head to head they finish within a few seconds of each other.
(I was hoping with this being a dedicated machine it would be a little quicker then my current machine. )

The largest cup you can place under the dispenser with the bottom removed is 7 1/2 inches. I am able to run 2 14oz cycles into my 32oz cup as I show in my 4th picture. Plenty of coffee for the drive or ride to work.

Before you use this to make coffee to drink, run several 14oz cycles until the hot water you get is clear. I was seeing tiny black flakes in the water for several cycles. I am thinking this is Teflon bits coming off the heating element after manufacturing & by doing this you clear out the debris. It did get less & less. After 4 cups of clear water I figured it was good to go.

For single servings I do like this over my 2-way. As you fill the reservoir on the side, you have water available for several cups. You also can select the amount you want by a button. On the 2-way you fill the reservoir with how much you want to make & need to do this for every cup.

This is not programmable so you will need to press the brew button to make your coffee in the morning instead of this having it ready for you when you wake up (not an issue for myself).
You will need to clean up water from time to time with a rag or paper towel under where the reservoir sits as a little can leak when you are removing or replacing the water tank on the side.

This is not that much smaller then the FlexBrew 2-way maker. If you want or need a new coffee maker for both full size pots & the ability to use k-cups or make single servings, spend a little extra and get the FlexBrew 2-way maker.

If all you need is a a single cup maker for home or office, this is a great and flexible (and cheaper) alternative to a Keurig or other single coffee makers. I am enjoying using this at work.

review name: Better than Keurig for a lower price.
review text:
I've never bothered to review an item not purchased at Amazon, but after several months I'm so pleased with this maker (having previously used two different Keurigs) that I can't resist trying. I'll keep it simple.
While the brewer takes slightly longer to work and is a little noisy at the beginning and end of the process, it makes a better cup of coffee. This may be because the temperature of the cup you make is higher than you get with Keurig and, when you use the strong (bold?) brew setting you can actually taste the difference, something I never noticed with the other brand. Here, my guess is that the delivery of the water through the pod is slower and more measured generates this result. The freedom to easily use your own ground coffee very simply is a plus.
Are there negatives? Gee, it doesn't have a clock. Oh, and the reservoir is only about 60% the size of my old Keurig (a very slight bother for the lazy). Boo Hoo. Weigh the pluses and minuses. Make your choice. I'll admit that the noise factor a mentioned at the start may be the result of some sort of friction, which could mean that the brewer won't last forever---but neither did my Keurigs and I'll happily take my chances.

review text:
I am not happy to give this Hamilton Beach FlexBrew coffeemaker such a low rating, but I have to give an honest review. There is so much I actually liked about this coffeemaker, especially the fact I could use either k-cups or regular ground coffee. I liked the fact that it had a fill tank of 40 oz, or 4 cups of coffee before I had to refill. It takes up a bit more counter space than my one-cup Mr. Coffee keurig coffee maker, but that was OK with me. All that said, at this point I am either going to give away the coffeemaker (with warning) or throw it away because I have done everything I can, and everything recommended by the manufacturer, to get rid of a horrid plastic/chemical taste. I read the manual and followed instructions to wash the coffeemaker out with hot soapy water, rinse well, etc. Then I followed their instructions to get of the bad taste by running vinegar through the coffeemaker. In fact, I followed that procedure twice, rinsing well with clean water after. I am sad to say it didn't work. I contacted the manufacturer via their web site to tell them what I'd done, and ask for further suggestions. Their return email simply sent me the instructions on running vinegar through the pot. I sent a return email to explain (again) that I'd already tried the vinegar process, but that it didn't work, and to ask, again, for any further suggestions. The return email simply said No, Sorry. And, despite knowing I was going to review this coffeemaker for Amazon Vine, they offered no solution. This isn't just a faint "new" plastic taste. This chemical taste makes the coffee undrinkable. I even took the appliance apart and let it "air out" on my counter for several days, then re-washed it, then ran the vinegar process again -- to no avail. Both coffee and tea are undrinkable.
I don't like to give negative reviews, especially when I'm receiving a product for free in exchange for my review, but I'm always going to be honest. Another coffeemaker may not have this problem, but based on my experience, I simply can't recommend it.

review text: I freely admit that when I first saw a K-cup brewing machine my reaction was a bit, well, snobbish. Huh, people are now too lazy to even make a simple cup of coffee, I thought. But I saw more and more of them, and then I had the opportunity to test a single-cup brewer in my home. I went through the supplied sample pods, bought some more, and before long I was regularly buying K-cup pods in different blends and brands, and I was really enjoying it. It doesn’t cost that much, and it’s a lot more convenient that having to grind a tablespoon of beans every morning and run them through a Melita filter or French press, not to mention a lot neater, and probably a lot less wasteful. Most of the K-cups I was buying had really good, fresh, coffee in them, too. In fact, the only drawback to my new coffeemaker was that the reservoir had to be refilled for every cup, which was very inconvenient when I had company over. This Hamilton Beach K-cup brewer promised to solve that problem. It’s easy to use, and thanks to the water reservoir it can produce coffee fast enough for at least a small gathering without making anyone wait too long. Controls are simple: Choose the cup size, and hit one of the two brew buttons to choose the strength. (It also has the ability to connect with your smart phone and automatically order coffee for you, a function that might make sense on an ink jet printer but that I don’t see using in a coffee maker.) And if you do feel like grinding your own beans, it comes with three reusable K-cups that you can fill with your own blends. It’s been in daily use on my kitchen counter for about three weeks now without any problems.

If you only use the insert for the Keurig cups, this unit can also be used to just make hot water for tea. One last thing, for curiosity, I checked the price for replacements and found that they are very affordable, which I really appreciated. So, all in all, I really love the machine. review text: I have had a Hamilton Beach coffee maker for the past 20+ years. I had one with the carafe plus the single serve but would not accommodate k-cups. I finally decided that I needed one that would take them so that when I had company, I could serve people whatever their preference was. One of the main things I love is that you can make a 14 oz. travel mug of coffee with their grounds attachment. That is what I always used with my previous machine.
